At the end of the 1990s, with [[Benny Lévy]] and [[Alain Finkielkraut]], Lévy founded an Institute on [[Emmanuel Levinas|Levinassian]] Studies at Jerusalem, in honor of [[Emmanuel Levinas]].http://www.levinas.fr/institut/institut.asp He is member of nonprofit advocacy group [[JCall]]. In March 2006, Lévy was one of twelve signatories of a letter entitled, "[[MANIFESTO: Together facing the new totalitarianism]]."' addressing concerns for free speech and thought in response to violent and deadly protests in the [[Muslim world]] related to the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy]] that arose in Denmark. ===Books=== ====''Who Killed Daniel Pearl?''==== In 2003, Lévy wrote an account of his efforts to track the murderer of [[Daniel Pearl]], the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reporter who was taken captive and beheaded by Islamic extremists the previous year. At the time of Pearl's death, Lévy was visiting [[Afghanistan]] as French President [[Jacques Chirac]]'s special envoy.{{cite journal|last=Graff|first=James|date=4 May 2003|title=The Engaged Intellect|volume=161|issue=19|journal=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,449446,00.html|quote=The Envoy: At the request of French President Jacques Chirac, Lévy traveled to Afghanistan in February 2002 to gauge the needs of the Afghan people... }} He spent the next year in Pakistan, India, Europe and the United States trying to uncover why Pearl's captors held and executed him. The resulting book, ''Who Killed Daniel Pearl?'', argues it was because Pearl knew too much about the links between Pakistan's [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] and [[al-Qaeda]]. The book was strongly criticized by both experts and Pearl's own family, including wife [[Mariane Pearl]] who called Lévy "a man whose intelligence is destroyed by his own ego".[[Nicolas Beau]] and Olivier Toscer, ''Une imposture française'', Éditions des Arènes, 2006.{{cite web|last1=Levy|first1=Justine|title=Justine Levy, Daughter of French Public Intellectual BHL, Writes What She Knows: Life|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2015/02/27/justine-levy-daughter-of-french-public-intellectual-bhl-writes-what-she-knows-life/|website=Jewishbusinessnews|accessdate=19 August 2015}} The book was condemned by [[William Dalrymple (historian)|William Dalrymple]], a British historian of India and travel writer, and others, for its lack of rigour and its caricatured depictions of Pakistani society. Dalrymple also criticized Lévy's fictionalised account of Pearl's thoughts in the last moments of his life.Escobar, Pepe, [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/EF28Df02.html "Who killed Daniel Pearl?" (review)], ''Asia Times'' (28 June 2003). Retrieved 19 May 2011.Dalrymple, William, [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/16823 "Murder in Karachi"], ''The New York Review of Books'', 4 December 2003. Retrieved 19 May 2011.[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/16903 "'Murder in Karachi': An Exchange"] (Bernard-Henri Levy and William Dalrymple), ''The New York Review of Books'', 12 February 2004. Retrieved 19 May 2011.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/hardtalk/3208461.stm|work=BBC News|title=Who Killed Daniel Pearl?|date=23 October 2003|accessdate=26 April 2010}} ====''In the Footsteps of Tocqueville''==== Although Lévy's books have been translated into the English language since ''La Barbarie à visage humain'', his breakthrough in gaining a wider US audience was the publication of a series of essays between May and November 2005 for ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]],'' later collected as a book.{{cite news|last=Keillor|first=Garrison|title=On the Road Avec M. Lévy|work=The New York Times|page=1|date=29 January 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/29/books/review/29keillor.html}} In preparation for the series, ''In the Footsteps of Tocqueville'', Lévy criss-crossed the United States, interviewing Americans, and recording his observations, with direct reference to his claimed predecessor, [[Alexis de Tocqueville]]. His work was published in serial form in the magazine and collected as a book by the same title. The book was widely criticized in the United States, with [[Garrison Keillor]] publishing a damning review on the front page of the ''[[New York Times Book Review]]''. ====''The Spirit of Judaism''==== In February 2016, Lévy published a new book entitled ''L'Esprit du Judaisme''. An English version, ''The Genius of Judaism'', was published by [[Random House]] in January 2017. In his foreword he describes this work as "a sequel, 40 years later" to ''Testament de Dieu'', his earlier, widely considered seminal, opus. The book explores the reasons why the State of Israel is considered to be a litmus test for Jews and non-Jews alike; as well as the roots and causes of [[anti-Semitism]] where it existed, still exists, or is newly nascent. But, most of all, the book is devoted to Levy's ″defense of a certain idea of man and God, of history and time, of power, voice, light, sovereignty, revolt, memory, and nature—an idea that contains what I call, in homage to one of the few really great French writers to have understood some of its mystery, the genius of Judaism.″{{cite web|url=http://www.momentmag.com/bernard-henri-levy/|title=Bernard-Henri Lévy|date=4 November 2015|publisher=}} ==Representation in other media== ===In film=== Lévy directed the widely panned 1997 romance film ''[[Day and Night (1997 film)|Day and Night]]''.{{cite film|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119418/ |title=Le jour et la nuit |first=Bernard-Henri |last=Lévy |date=12 February 1997 |location=France}} It is considered by critics [[List of films considered the worst|the worst film of 1997]] along with ''[[Batman & Robin (film)|Batman & Robin]]''. The movie received a 3.5 million francs public subsidy through the ''Commission des avances sur recettes'', which at the time was chaired by Lévy.[[François-Xavier Ajavon]], [http://www.nanarland.com/divers/divers.php?id=8 "Symbolisme et temporalité bergsonnienne dans ''Le Jour et la Nuit'' de Bernard-Henri Levy"], Nanarland. In 2007, Italian conceptual artist, [[Francesco Vezzoli]], created two commercials for an imaginary U.S. presidential campaign, in which he had actress [[Sharon Stone]] running against Bernard-Henri Lévy. His project entitled ''Democrazy,'' was shown at the 2007 [[Venice Biennale]]. ===Pie throwing=== Bernard Henri Lévy is a favorite victim of [[pie throwing|pie thrower]] [[Noël Godin]].''Bernard-Henry Lévy à nouveau "entarté" en Belgique'', [http://www.liberation.fr/depeches/2015/05/30/bernard-henry-levy-a-nouveau-entarte-en-belgique_1319980]. ===Recent activities=== [[File:Bernard-Henri Lévy-tau-2.jpg|thumb|Bernard-Henri Lévy at [[Tel Aviv University]]]] In September 2008, Lévy toured the United States to promote his book ''[[Left in Dark Times: A Stand Against the New Barbarism]]''. In 2006, Lévy joined the [[British debate over veils|British debate over Muslim women's veils]] by suggesting to ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' that wearing a veil had the effect of dehumanizing the wearer by hiding her face – and said, alluding to a passage by [[Emmanuel Levinas]], that "the veil is an invitation to rape".''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'', 14 October 2006. Not available online, quote in context: "Our time is almost up, but BHL becomes the most animated I have seen him when I ask him about Jack Straw's intervention on Muslim women and the veil. 'Jack Straw', he says, leaning close to me, 'made a great point. He did not say that he was against the veil. He said it is much easier, much more comfortable, respectful, to speak with a woman with a naked face. And without knowing, he quoted [[Emmanuel Lévinas|Levinas]], who is the philosopher of the face. Levinas says that [having seen] the naked face of your interlocutor, you cannot kill him or her, you cannot rape him, you cannot violate him. So when the Muslims say that the veil is to protect women, it is the contrary. The veil is an invitation to rape.{{'"}} On 24 June 2009, Lévy posted a video on [[Dailymotion]] in support of the [[2009 Iranian election protests|Iranian protesters who were being repressed after the contested elections]].[http://www.dailymotion.com/user/BernardHL/video/x9o0n8_message-to-the-young-people-of-iran_news Message to the Young People of Iran by Bernard-Henri Lévy – une vidéo Nieuws & Politiek]. Dailymotion. Retrieved 19 May 2011. He is a member of the Selection Committee of the Editions Grasset, and he runs the ''La Règle du Jeu'' ("The Rule of the Game") magazine. He writes a weekly column in the magazine ''Le Point'' and chairs the Conseil de Surveillance of [[Arte|La Sept-Arte]]. Through the 2000s, Lévy argued that the world must pay more attention to the [[Darfur genocide|crisis in Darfur]]. In ''Left in Dark Times'', he argued that the Darfur genocide was not a palatable issue for modern leftists because it did not provide a platform for the anti-American views with which he says leftist thought has become suffused. In January 2010, he publicly defended Popes [[Pius XII]] and [[Benedict XVI]] against political attacks directed against them from within the Jewish community.[http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/1505/Monde/article/detail/1056957/2010/01/20/Bernard-Henri-Levy-defend-Benoit-XVI-et-Pie-XII.dhtml "Bernard-Henri Lévy défend Benoît XVI et Pie XII"]. 7sur7.be, 20 January 2010. Retrieved 19 May 2011. At the opening of the "Democracy and its Challenges" conference in [[Tel Aviv]] (May 2010) Lévy gave a very high estimation of the [[Israel Defense Forces]], saying "I have never seen such a democratic army, which asks itself so many moral questions. There is something unusually vital about Israeli democracy."{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/bernard-henri-levy-i-have-never-seen-an-army-as-democratic-as-the-idf-1.293087|author=Or Kashti|title=Bernard Henri Levy: I have never seen an army as democratic as the IDF|work=Haaretz|date=30 May 2010| accessdate=1 June 2010}} Lévy has reported from troubled zones during wartime, to attract public opinion, in France and abroad, over those political changes. In August 2008, Lévy reported from South Ossetia, Georgia, during the [[2008 South Ossetia war]]; on that occasion he interviewed the President of Georgia, [[Mikheil Saakashvili]].Bernard-Henri Lévy, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bernardhenri-levy/georgia-at-war-what-i-saw_b_120076.html "Georgia at War: What I Saw"], ''The Huffington Post'', 20 August 2008. In March 2011, he engaged in talks with Libyan rebels in [[Benghazi]], and publicly promoted the international acknowledgement of the recently formed [[National Transitional Council]].[http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xhdrv8_l-appel-de-bhl-depuis-benghazi-libye-en-direct-sur-tf1-au_news L'appel de BHL depuis Benghazi (Libye) en direct sur TF1 au – une vidéo Nieuws & Politiek]. Dailymotion. Retrieved 19 May 2011.Robert Marquand, [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2011/0328/How-a-philosopher-swayed-France-s-response-on-Libya|+World%29 "How a philosopher swayed France's response on Libya"]. ''The Christian Science Monitor'', 28 March 2011. Retrieved 19 May 2011. Later that month, worried about the [[2011 Libyan civil war]], he prompted and then supported [[Nicolas Sarkozy]]'s seeking to persuade Washington, and ultimately the United Nations, to intervene in Libya to prevent a massacre in Benghazi.Steven Erlanger, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/africa/02levy.html?_r=1 "By His Own Reckoning, One Man Made Libya a French Cause"], ''The New York Times'', 1 April 2011. In May 2011, Lévy defended IMF Chief [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]] when Kahn was accused of sexually assaulting a chambermaid in New York City. Lévy questioned the credibility of the charges against Strauss-Kahn, asking ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', "how a chambermaid could have walked in alone, contrary to the habitual practice of most of New York's grand hotels of sending a 'cleaning brigade' of two people, into the room of one of the most closely watched figures on the planet."[http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-05-16/bernard-henri-lvy-the-dominique-strauss-kahn-i-know/ "Dominique Strauss-Kahn: Bernard-Henri Lévy Defends IMF Director"]. ''[[The Daily Beast]]''. Retrieved 19 May 2011.{{cite news|last=Dowd|first=Maureen|title=Powerful and Primitive|work=The New York Times|date=18 May 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/18/opinion/18dowd.html}} In May 2011, Lévy argued for military intervention in Syria against [[Bashar al-Assad]] after violence against civilians in response to the [[2011 Syrian uprising]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/world/88662/bashar-al-assad-syria-qaddafi-arab-spring|author=Bernard-Henri Levy|title=After Qaddafi, Assad|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=19 May 2011|accessdate=24 May 2011}} He repeated his position in a letter to the [[Weekly Standard]] in August 2013.Daniel Halper, [http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/experts-obama-here-what-do-syria_751267.html "Experts to Obama: Here Is What to Do in Syria"], ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'', 27 August 2013. On 9 November 2011, his book, ''La guerre sans l'aimer'', which tells the story of his Libyan spring, was published.[http://www.bernard-henri-levy.com/cinq-bonnes-raisons-de-devorer-le-dernier-bhl-atlantico-le-8-novembre-2011-article-de-mry-24393.html "Cinq bonnes raisons de dévorer le dernier BHL"], ''Atlantico'', 8 November 2011, MRY[http://www.lemonde.fr/libye/article/2011/11/08/bhl-porte-etendard-libyen_1600481_1496980.html? "La légende dorée de BHL en Libye"], ''Le Monde''. 7 November 2011}[http://www.bernard-henri-levy.com/bhl-en-libye-sur-les-traces-de-lawrence-darabie-rue89-le-7-novembre-2011-article-de-pierre-haski-24373.html "BHL en Libye, sur les traces de Lawrence d'Arabie"], ''Rue89'', 7 November 2011, Pierre HaskiSébastien Le Fol, [http://www.bernard-henri-levy.com/bernard-henri-levy-en-libye-la-guerre-intime-le-figaro-le-8-novembre-2011-article-de-sebastien-le-fol-24381.html "Bernard-Henri Lévy en Libye, la guerre intime"], ''Le Figaro'', 8 November 2011. In April 2013, he was convicted by a French court for libelling journalist [[Bernard Cassen]].[http://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/carnet/2013-04-26-BHL "Même la justice française condamne BHL..."], ''Le Monde Diplomatique'', 26 April 2013. Lévy curated a major art exhibition in 2013 entitled ''Adventures of truth – Painting and philosophy: a narrative'' at the [[Maeght Foundation]]. He criticized the international community for their acts during the [[Bosnia genocide]].{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bernardhenri-levy/the-significance-of-saraj_b_4148799.html |work=Huffington Post |first=Bernard-Henri |last=Lévy |title=The Significance of Sarajevo |date=23 October 2013}} Levy was in Kiev, Ukraine during the [[2014 Ukrainian Revolution|Maidan Revolution]] in February 2014, actively promoting the events.{{cite news| url=http://www.kyivpost.com/opinion/op-ed/bernard-henri-levy-remembering-the-maidan-385357.html |work=Kyiv Post |first=Bernard-Henri |last=Levy |title=Bernard-Henri Levy: Remembering the Maidan |date=4 April 2015}} In February 2015, he performed his play ''Hotel Europa'' at the Kiev opera house on the first anniversary of the Euromaidan's toppling of the pro-Russian government of Victor Yanukovich.{{Cite news|title = Bernard-Henri Levy will perform his 'Hotel Europe' play in Kyiv's opera house on Feb. 21|url = http://test.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/bernard-henri-levy-will-perform-his-hotel-europe-play-in-kyivs-opera-house-on-feb-21-380982.html|work=Kyiv Post|date=18 February 2015|accessdate = 16 December 2015}} In April 2014, he visited Bangladesh for the first time since 1972 to speak at the launch of the first Bengali translation of his first book ''Bangla-Desh, Nationalisme dans la révolution'' ("Bangladesh, Nationalism in the Revolution", 1973), and to open a memorial garden for Malraux at Dhaka University. On 5 June 2018 he performed his one-man play ''Last Exit before Brexit'' at the [[Cadogan Hall]] in London. The play is a revised version of ''Hotel Europa'' and argues passionately that [[Brexit]] should be abandoned.{{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/jun/05/please-please-remain-bernard-henri-levy-performs-one-man-brexit-play|title='Please, please remain': Bernard-Henri Lévy performs one-man Brexit play|date=5 June 2018|access-date=6 June 2018| website=theguardian.com}} Lévy has also been regularly contributing to Project Syndicate since 2015. Lévy's involvement with the [[Kurds|Kurdish]] cause goes back to the early 1990s.{{cite web | last=Cohen | first=Ben | title=Bernard-Henri Lévy: Jews Have 'Special Obligation' to Support Kurdish Independence | website=Algemeiner.com | date=September 25, 2017 | url=https://www.algemeiner.com/2017/09/25/bernard-henri-levy-jews-have-special-obligation-to-support-kurdish-independence/ | access-date=April 3, 2018}} On May 16, 2016, Bernard-Henri Lévy's new documentary film, ''Peshmerga'', was chosen by the Cannes film festival as a special screening to its official selection.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-festival-adds-peshmerga-official-894343|title=Cannes Adds Bernard-Henri Levy's 'Peshmerga' to Official Selection|publisher=}} The movie itself is, as stated in its official Cannes presentation: "The third part of a trilogy, opus three of a documentary made and lived in real time, the missing piece of the puzzle of a lifetime, the desperate search for enlightened Islam. Where is that other Islam strong enough to defeat the Islam of the fundamentalists? Who embodies it? Who sustains it? Where are the men and women who in word and deed strive for that enlightened Islam, the Islam of law and human rights, an Islam that stands for women and their rights, that is faithful to the lofty thinking of Averroes, Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani, Ibn Tufail, and Rumi?... Here, with this third film, this hymn to Kurdistan and the exception that it embodies, I have the feeling of possibly reaching my goal. Kurdistan is Sunnis and Shiites, Chaldeans, Assyrians, Aramaic-speaking Syrians living freely with Muslims, the memory of the Jews of Aqrah, secularism, freedom of conscience and belief. It is where one can run into a Jewish Barzani on the forward line of a front held, 50 kilometers from Erbil, by his distant cousin, a Muslim, Sirwan Barazi… Better than the Arab Spring. The Bosnian dream achieved. My dream. There is no longer really any doubt. Enlightened Islam exists: I found it in Erbil."{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/en/article/62158.html|title=Festival de Cannes - Site Officiel / Institutionnel|website=Festival de Cannes}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/islamic-state-will-be-defeated-1441233971|title=Islamic State Will Be Defeated|first=Bernard-Henri|last=Lévy|date=2 September 2015|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}} A year later, Lévy said that "Jews have a special obligation to support the Kurds," and that he hopes "they will come say to the Peshmerga: 'For years now you have spilled your blood to defend the values of our shared civilization. Now it is our turn to defend your right to live freely and independently.'" ==Criticisms== Early essays, such as ''Le Testament de Dieu'' or ''L'Idéologie française'' faced strong rebuttals from noted intellectuals on all sides of the ideological spectrum, such as historian [[Pierre Vidal-Naquet]] and philosophers [[Cornelius Castoriadis]], [[Raymond Aron]], and [[Gilles Deleuze]], who called Lévy's methods "vile".Gilles Deleuze, [http://www.acrimed.org/A-propos-des-nouveaux-philosophes-et-d-un-probleme-plus-general-Gilles-Deleuze A propos des nouveaux philosophes et d'un problème plus général], first published in May 1977 More recently, Lévy was publicly embarrassed when his essay ''De la guerre en philosophie'' (2010) cited the writings of French "philosopher" [[Jean-Baptiste Botul]].{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article7019866.ece|work=The Times|location=London|title=BernardHenri Lvy a laughing stock for quoting fictional philosopher|date=9 February 2010|accessdate=26 April 2010|first=Charles|last=Bremner}} Botul's writings are actually well-known spoofs, and Botul himself is the purely fictional creation of a living French journalist and philosopher, [[Frédéric Pagès]]. The obviousness of the hoax led to suspicions that Levy had not read Botul, and that he consequently might have used a [[ghostwriter]] for his book. Responding in an opinion piece, Levy wrote: "It was a truly brilliant and very believable hoax from the mind of a Canard Enchaîné journalist who remains a good philosopher all the same. So I was caught, as were the critics who reviewed the book when it came out. The only thing left to say, with no hard feelings, is kudos to the artist."{{cite news|last=Carvajal|first=Doreen|title=Philosopher Left to Muse on Ridicule Over a Hoax|work=The New York Times|page=4|date=10 February 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/10/world/europe/10levy.html}} In the essay ''Une imposture française'', journalists Nicolas Beau and Olivier Toscer claim that Lévy uses his unique position as an influential member of both the literary and business establishments in France to be the go-between of the two worlds, which helps him to get positive reviews as marks of gratitude, while silencing dissenters.{{cite web|title=BHL: les dessous d'un système|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/livre/une-imposture-francaise_811125.html|website=L'EXPRESS|accessdate=19 August 2015}} For instance, Beau and Toscer noted that most of the reviews published in France for ''Who Killed Daniel Pearl?'' didn't mention strong denials about the book given by experts and Pearl's own family including wife [[Mariane Pearl]] who called Lévy "a man whose intelligence is destroyed by his own ego".{{cite web|last1=Lévy|first1=Justine|title=Justine Levy, Daughter of French Public Intellectual BHL, Writes What She Knows: Life|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2015/02/27/justine-levy-daughter-of-french-public-intellectual-bhl-writes-what-she-knows-life/|website=Jewishbusinessnews|accessdate=19 August 2015}} ==Personal life== Lévy has been married three times. His eldest daughter by his first marriage to Isabelle Doutreluigne, [[Justine Lévy]], is a best-selling novelist. He has a son, Antonin-Balthazar Lévy, by his second wife, Sylvie Bouscasse. He is currently married to French actress and singer [[Arielle Dombasle]]. The close relationship between Lévy and heiress and socialite [[Daphne Guinness]] has become something of an open secret known and acknowledged by most US society columnists since 2008. On 13 July 2010, Daphne Guinness confirmed the whole story in the UK press.Derek Blasberg, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/12/daphne-guinness-bernardhe_n_822322.html "Daphne Guinness: Bernard-Henri Levy ‘Is Quite Obviously The Love Of My Life’"], ''Huffington Post'', 12 February 2011. Lévy is proudly [[Jewish]], and he has said that Jews ought to provide a unique Jewish moral voice in society and politics.[http://www.leadel.net/talks/environment-science/bernard-henri-levy environment-science | Leading Jewish Inspiration] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307015108/http://www.leadel.net/talks/environment-science/bernard-henri-levy |date=7 March 2009 }}. Leadel. Retrieved 19 May 2011. Lévy has been friends with [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] since 1983. Relations between them deteriorated during Sarkozy's 2007 presidential run in which Lévy backed the Socialist candidate and also described Sarkozy as "A man with a warrior vision of politics". However, they grew closer again after Sarkozy's victory.Christopher Dickey, [http://www.newsweek.com/why-sarkozy-went-war-66463 "Why Sarkozy Went to War"]. ''Newsweek'' (3 April 2011). Retrieved 19 May 2011. Much of his recent book, ''Left in Dark Times'', is devoted to explaining his refusal to support Sarkozy despite agreeing with him on many points, and his insistence on continuing to identify himself as a leftist despite rejecting much of modern leftist thought. In 2004, his fortune amounts to 150 million euros. Owner of seven companies, its fortune comes essentially from the inheritance of his parents, then completed by stock exchange investments (he is in 2000 suspected of [[insider trading]] by the ''Commission des opérations de bourse'').{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/faits-divers/un-heritier-devenu-milliardaire-27-10-2004-2005406567.php|title=Un héritier devenu milliardaire|date=26 October 2004|publisher=}} ==Threats== Lévy was one of six prominent Jewish public figures in Europe targeted for assassination by a Belgium-based [[Islamist]] militant group in 2008. The list included others in France such as [[Josy Eisenberg]]. That plot was reportedly foiled after the group's leader, [[Abdelkader Belliraj]], was arrested based on unrelated murder charges from the 1980s.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1051943.html "Bernard Henri Levy among 6 Jews said targeted by Islamist group"], ''Haaretz'' (1 January 2009). Retrieved 19 May 2011. ==Works== Lévy's works have been translated into many different languages; below is an offering of works available in either French or English. * ''{{lang|fr|Bangla-Desh, Nationalisme dans la révolution}}'', 1973 (reissued in 1985 under the title ''Les Indes Rouges''). * ''{{lang|fr|La barbarie à visage humain}}'', 1977. * "Response to the Master Censors".
